CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Figure 10 shows the AFM images of the polymer : PC71BM ( 1 : 5 wt % ) films , which were taken after removal of the Al electrode and after device fabrication. The Al electrode was removed by dipping the devices for 1 min in a mixed acid solution containing of 16 mL of concentrated phosphoric acid , 1 mL of concentrated hydrochloric acid , 1 mL of acetic acid , and 2 mL of D 2 O. The blend films showed almost equivalently measured smooth surfaces ( according to their root-mean-square ( rms ) roughness ) with small degrees of phase separation. The rms roughness of the active layers were 0.49 nm for PFDTBT , 0.44 nm for PFDTBT-10Per , 0.51 nm for PFD2TBT , and 0.50 nm for PFD2TBT-10Per , respectively. This result suggests that the morphologies of all the active films are very similar , so that such a property will not affect the J sc of the photovoltaic devices. Therefore , the improvement of PCE and J sc in the fabricated photovoltaic devices is derived from the enhanced π-π interaction between polymers that results from the introduction of perylene units . We introduced perylene units into PFDTBT and PFD2TBT to enhance the interchain π-π interaction. The optical and electrochemical properties of the synthesized copolymers showed were slight modification upon perylene addition. Interestingly , the field - effect mobility of the TFTs , using the polymers as the active layer increased with an increasing perylene content in the copolymers. The short circuit currents of the photovoltaic devices fabricated using the polymers as an electron donor , also increased as the perylene content in the copolymers increased , which is consistent with the field - effect mobility results of the polymers. We conclude that the introduction of perylene to the conjugated polymer chain enhances the π-π interaction between polymer chains and improves its charge - transport ability , leading to increases short circuit currents in the photovoltaic devices . Corresponding Author *E - mail : dohoonhwang @ pusan.ac.kr .

Let's think step by step.

1. "PC71BM" is a material name. It is a type of polymer.
2. "PFDTBT" is a material name. It is another type of polymer.
3. "PFDTBT-10Per" is a material name. It is a copolymer made from PFDTBT and perylene.
4. "PFD2TBT" is a material name. It is yet another type of polymer.
5. "PFD2TBT-10Per" is a material name. It is a copolymer made from PFD2TBT and perylene.
6. "perylene" is a material name. It is a chemical compound that is introduced into PFDTBT and PFD2TBT to enhance their properties.
7. "Al" is a material name. It is the material of the electrode that is removed from the devices.
8. "phosphoric acid" is a material name. It is one of the components of the mixed acid solution used to remove the Al electrode.
9. "hydrochloric acid" is a material name. It is another component of the mixed acid solution used to remove the Al electrode.
10. "acetic acid" is a material name. It is another component of the mixed acid solution used to remove the Al electrode.
11. "D 2 O" is a material name. It is another component of the mixed acid solution used to remove the Al electrode.

These are the material names that I was able to identify in the paragraph. Let me know if you have any questions or if there is anything else I can help you with.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. "PC71BM"
2. "PFDTBT"
3. "PFDTBT-10Per"
4. "PFD2TBT"
5. "PFD2TBT-10Per"
6. "perylene"
7. "Al"

These are the material names that I was able to identify in the paragraph. I have removed any entities that do not clearly refer to a material name. Let me know if you have any questions or if there is anything else I can help you with.

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Figure 10 shows the AFM images of the polymer : PC71BM ( 1 : 5 wt % ) films , which were taken after removal of the Al electrode and after device fabrication. The Al electrode was removed by dipping the devices for 1 min in a mixed acid solution containing of 16 mL of concentrated phosphoric acid , 1 mL of concentrated hydrochloric acid , 1 mL of acetic acid , and 2 mL of D 2 O. The blend films showed almost equivalently measured smooth surfaces ( according to their root-mean-square ( rms ) roughness ) with small degrees of phase separation. The rms roughness of the active layers were 0.49 nm for PFDTBT , 0.44 nm for PFDTBT-10Per , 0.51 nm for PFD2TBT , and 0.50 nm for PFD2TBT-10Per , respectively. This result suggests that the morphologies of all the active films are very similar , so that such a property will not affect the J sc of the photovoltaic devices. Therefore , the improvement of PCE and J sc in the fabricated photovoltaic devices is derived from the enhanced π-π interaction between polymers that results from the introduction of perylene units . We introduced perylene units into PFDTBT and PFD2TBT to enhance the interchain π-π interaction. The optical and electrochemical properties of the synthesized copolymers showed were slight modification upon perylene addition. Interestingly , the field - effect mobility of the TFTs , using the polymers as the active layer increased with an increasing perylene content in the copolymers. The short circuit currents of the photovoltaic devices fabricated using the polymers as an electron donor , also increased as the perylene content in the copolymers increased , which is consistent with the field - effect mobility results of the polymers. We conclude that the introduction of perylene to the conjugated polymer chain enhances the π-π interaction between polymer chains and improves its charge - transport ability , leading to increases short circuit currents in the photovoltaic devices . Corresponding Author *E - mail : dohoonhwang @ pusan.ac.kr .

Let's think step by step.

1. The paragraph mentions the use of a mixed acid solution with specific volumes of different acids: 16 mL of concentrated phosphoric acid, 1 mL of concentrated hydrochloric acid, 1 mL of acetic acid, and 2 mL of D_{2}O. These volumes are all given in milliliters (mL).
2. The root-mean-square (rms) roughness of the active layers of the polymer films is given as: 0.49 nm for PFDTBT, 0.44 nm for PFDTBT-10Per, 0.51 nm for PFD2TBT, and 0.50 nm for PFD2TBT-10Per. These values are given in nanometers (nm).
3. The optical and electrochemical properties of the synthesized copolymers showed "slight modification" upon perylene addition. However, the specific values of these properties are not provided in the paragraph.
4. The field-effect mobility of the TFTs using the polymers as the active layer increased with an increasing perylene content in the copolymers. Again, the specific values of the field-effect mobility are not provided in the paragraph.
5. The short circuit currents of the photovoltaic devices fabricated using the polymers as an electron donor increased as the perylene content in the copolymers increased. The specific values of the short circuit currents are not provided in the paragraph.

In summary, the paragraph provides the following values related to material properties:

* 16 mL of concentrated phosphoric acid
* 1 mL of concentrated hydrochloric acid
* 1 mL of acetic acid
* 2 mL of D_{2}O
* 0.49 nm for PFDTBT
* 0.44 nm for PFDTBT-10Per
* 0.51 nm for PFD2TBT
* 0.50 nm for PFD2TBT-10Per

The paragraph also mentions the modification of optical and electrochemical properties and the increase in field-effect mobility and short circuit currents upon perylene addition, but it does not provide specific values for these properties.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

* 16 mL (concentrated phosphoric acid)
* 1 mL (concentrated hydrochloric acid)
* 1 mL (acetic acid)
* 2 mL (D2O)
* 0.49 nm (PFDTBT)
* 0.44 nm (PFDTBT-10Per)
* 0.51 nm (PFD2TBT)
* 0.50 nm (PFD2TBT-10Per)
